ROBERT FIELD: OK, so
the goal is to get

a little bit of a sense of what
do we do when molecules are not rigid?

And the way I'm going
to approach this is to show that there is,
in fact, a serious problem

that you would have
encountered in 562.

And you would have
been wondering about how you deal with this. And then I'm going to
see what we can do.

So we're going to start
with nuclear spins.

And we're going to be talking
about ortho-para states

and nuclear statistical weights. And I will quickly go
through the standard material

from the elementary
statistical mechanics course, where you end up
seeing a rotational intensity

alternation in
homonuclear molecules. And we think we understand
that beautifully.

It seems to be a
wonderful thing. And then I'll say OK,
suppose we go from hydrogen,

which is 2 fermions,
to acetylene, which is 2 fermions and 2 bosons.

What do we do? All the simple ideas we had
in 562 or whatever course

you've seen this
go out the window, because it's not possible
to classify levels

or to construct levels which
satisfy the permutation

symmetry for both
hydrogens and carbons. So the next step will be to talk
about symmetric double minimum

problems to show that when there
are symmetric double minima,

the levels come in
degenerate pairs.

When the barrier is really
high, the degeneracy is perfect, and one could almost think
that only one level is there.

This is the way
around the problem. Whenever there are two or
more identical species,

the true degeneracy
of the level can be 2. And this is how we get
around the initial problem.

So then I will start talking
above my head about CNPI group theory, but only very briefly
unless there are questions

and they elicit some greater
knowledge than I thought I had. OK, so we start out with
hydrogen. And hydrogen--

we classify the
nuclei of molecules according to whether
they're bosons or fermions.

And we ask about
operations where nuclei, identical nuclei--

not chemically identical,
but identical-- when they are permuted.

And because you have
identical particles, the wave function has
to be odd with respect

to permutation of fermions
and even with respect to permutation of bosons.

And if it's not even
or odd with respect

to all such permutations, you've
written something which is not a legitimate wave function.

So for hydrogen, we
have to fermions. And the spin of each is 1/2.

And so the total nuclear
spin is either 0 or 1.

Now, it's required that
the overall permutation

symmetry, P12, for the wave
function, the total wave function, has to be equal
minus 1 times the wave
function for fermions.

and nuclear spin. I should have put nuclear
spin earlier in the list.

We don't ever have to
worry about translation, because all translational
wave functions

are symmetric with
respect to permutation. For homonuclear
diatomic molecules,

we don't have to worry
about vibrations. In fact, for all
diatomic molecules. Vibrations are
totally symmetric.

But this is not true for
polyatomic molecules. But we're going to
initially just talk

about hydrogen and deuterium and
oxygen and think we understand.

And then I will introduce
acetylene and we will realize, we don't. OK, so the electronic
symmetry, the permutations--

that's always a little puzzling. And I thought I
would have an answer to that too with a
nice picture, but I

don't have an answer to this. I can only say that for diatomic
molecule, states of sigma

plus g and sigma minus u have
positive permutation symmetry.

And states of sigma u
plus and sigma g minus--

so these are positive and
these are negative with respect to the permutation.

But I'd like to be able
to say why this is true. And it would be nice to be able
to say this with a diagram.

And I thought I had
it, but I don't. And so all I can
do is assert this. This is important for being
able to judge the permutation

symmetry of polyatomic
molecule electronic states. And also vibrational states,
especially when they're
vibrational angular momentum. But this I can say is true.

When you have doubly
degenerate states, there's always one
plus and one minus. So the critical thing is
when there's no degeneracy.

And so this is something
that you can remember. And whether that helps
you for other situations

remains to be seen. OK, so now for
diatomic molecules,

the permutation symmetry for psi
rotation is minus 1 to the n,

not j. Because n has to do with
the total angular momentum

exclusive of spin. And it's the nuclei
that are being permuted

in a rotation labeled by n. Now, for singlets, n
is the same thing as j. So that's just a subtle point.

And so in the elementary
statistical mechanics course,
you're told this.  And it seems reasonable.

And so now, since everything
else is pretty simple, in order

to get the right
symmetry, you have to pair the rotational
wave function with the correct
nuclear wave function.

So if you have spin
1/2, then we have a mnemonic for writing
the spin wave functions.

We can write alpha 1, beta 2
plus or minus alpha 2, beta 1.

And we can write alpha 1,
alpha 2 and beta 1, beta 2.

OK, spin up, spin down. So permutation on
this, positive.

Permutation on this, positive. Permutation on the
positive sign, positive.

Permutation on the
negative sign, negative. So what we have is three
states where P12 psi
nuclear is plus psi nuclear.

And those are called
triplet, believe it or not.
Nuclear spin triplets. And one state where P12--

where the nuclear
spin is negative. And that's called
nuclear spin singlet.

For the triplet, I
total is equal to 1.

And for the singlet,
I total is equal to 0. Again, big surprise.
Singlet and triplet. 2S plus 1 or 2I plus 1. OK, so what about--

all right. So for hydrogen then, that
means that we need a state.

Psi total P12 is
minus psi total.
And so even J have even--

so I wrote. So they must have odd nuclear
spin, odd permutation symmetry

nuclear. And so well-- so
the odd symmetry

nuclear spin is the singlet.  And so it has a nuclear
degeneracy of 1.

And the odd rotational
levels will require
an even symmetry, psi nuclear.

And those are the triplets,
nuclear spin equals 3.

These are called ortho,
and these are called para.

And it's always true that
the nuclear spin modification

called ortho is the one with the
higher nuclear spin degeneracy.

There's more letters
in ortho than para, you'll never forget it.

I mean, it's really
hard to remember, but one little stupid
mnemonic like that and you

can't forget it. I mean, para is like parallel,
but that doesn't help,

unless you want to do something. So the one that has the higher
nuclear spin statistical weight

is always ortho. So for hydrogen, we
have even J, odd J.

And the even J have odd
nuclear spin symmetry.

The odd nuclear spin
symmetry is singlet

and its para g nuclear spin
is 1 whereas the odd J have

the opposite, ortho
g, and this equals 3.

So for the ground
state of hydrogen,

you have a singlet
sigma g plus state

and the rotational
levels, 0, 1, 2.

We can label them according
to parity as well. And we can label them
according to nuclear spin.

And so this guy has a nuclear
spin singlet, it's para.

Another way of--
or, and g equals.

OK, another way of
remembering this is that it's always possible
to make pure para hydrogen.

And that's because
using a catalyst, you can always convert all of
the hydrogen to J equals 0.

And this is also a
good thing, because J equals 0 has a degeneracy,
rotational, and nuclear

of 1, which means that you can
make a perfect quantum solid,

because every particle in the
solid is in the same state

and they're close together. And so it is an isotropic
medium, bar none.

But so you've heard
of para hydrogen. You can make ortho hydrogen,
but you can't make it pure.

This you can make
incredibly pure

and you can make an incredibly
perfect quantum solid. AUDIENCE: What do you
mean by quantum solid?

ROBERT FIELD: Every
particle is spherical, every particle is
in the same state,

and they're close together. And so they know
about each other.

AUDIENCE: What? ROBERT FIELD: And so it's
the best possible matrix that you can put something
into, because the matrix
is totally isotropic.

And there's some wonderful
matrix isolation spectroscopy on para hydrogen, and
also on ortho hydrogen,
but it's not quite so simple. OK, so we have hydrogen.

Next to hydrogen
we have deuterium. And deuterium, the
nuclei have a spin of 1.

So the nuclei for deuterium
are bosons instead of fermions.

And so it turns out just
the other way around. So we can work this
out, but what you can do

is you can also describe the
various nuclear spins of 1,

instead of alpha and beta, you
can use three symbols, alpha, beta, and gamma or whatever you
want and classify the states.

And you can construct symmetric
and anti-symmetric states.

And what you find
is the states with I total equals 0 and
2 are symmetric.
Is that right?  And-- that's right.

And I total of 1
are anti-symmetric.

Total degeneracy,
1 plus 5, 6, and 3.
So here we have 1, 3, 1.

For deuterium, we
have 6, 6, , 3 6.

So we have a 3 to 1 intensity
alternation and a 1 to 2
intensity alternation. This state is ortho.

And so you can, in principle,
make pure ortho deuterium.

But ortho has two values
of the nuclear spin, total nuclear spin.

One of them has I equals 0,
the other one has I equals 2. So there are really six
distinct quantum states

associated with D2. And so even though
you can completely cool all of the deuterium
into J equals 0,

it's not a good quantum solid,
because there are six states, and 0 and 2 are not
even quite degenerate.

Not a big deal. OK, so this is all
very simple and people

get very excited in
562 when they see this. And there is this
incredible thing

when you look at the spectrum
of hydrogen and deuterium, you see an intensity
alternation.

This was not noticed
first because the spectrum

of hydrogen is in the vacuum
ultraviolet where there is-- I mean, it might have been
noticed in the Raman spectrum,

but the killer was not
hydrogen and deuterium.

But the intensity alternation
was first really understood and observed unambiguously
in the spectrum
of oxygen. And oxygen--

the oxygen nuclei are bosons. The ground state of oxygen
is singlet sigma g minus.
So this classifies as odd.
I covered it up somewhere. No, it's up there. So this is odd.

And now we have bosons. And so we need an
overall P12 psi
total equals plus psi total.

And so if the electronic
wave function is odd,

and there's no nuclear spins,
the nuclear spin function is even. It has degeneracy of 1, and
it's even, it's a singlet.

It's ortho, because
there's only one.

You can't have a para spin
function for a pair of nuclei.

OK, it's ortho. And so in order for this to
come out, you have to have--

for the overall nuclear spin
to come out to be positive,

you can only have odd
rotational levels.

So you have an energy
level diagram for oxygen and we have 0, 1, 2.

Now, this is n. Remember, oxygen has
a triplet sigma state,

so there are going to be J
sublevels of some of these.

And this one doesn't exist. And this one doesn't exist. So we only have half of
the rotational levels
of oxygen existing.

OK, and so if you
were going to look

at a spectrum, an
electronic spectrum, there isn't any other
spectrum of oxygen.

Although there is a
magnetic dipole allowed,

a microwave spectrum. But those are transitions
among the J levels associated

with the given n.  Because there's no state of
even n in ordinary oxygen.

Now, if you had
oxygen 16, oxygen 18,

then every level
would be present. Now, one of the really
wonderful things

about this nuclear
symmetry is that if you

have an allowed
transition-- let's say you have a transition
from the triplet sigma

g minus ground state, you could
have a transition to states

that have u symmetry And
the only possible states are
sigma u minus or triplet Iu.

Well, in triplet sigma
u minus, half the levels

will be missing also. But this, you see a minus and
a u, so this is an even state.

And so what's going to
happen is only the states

with even n are present. Only states have
odd n are present.

And if you didn't know
about nuclear spin, you'd there's no
Q branches here. And those are precisely
the transitions

that can't exist because
of the nuclear spin.

So one of the things
that if you've forgotten some of the group
theory or forgotten some stuff

and you want to check,
you say, OK, I'm interested in an
allowed transition.

I know from other less
sophisticated stuff how to predict which are going
to be the transitions that

are allowed.  A photon can't
flip nuclear spins.

And so the allowed
transitions will be to the same
nuclear spin species.

Oxygen has nothing
but ortho spins. And the excited state will have
nothing but ortho spins, ortho

states, rotational states. And the states that are
not-- the transitions that

are forbidden by
simple rules are also forbidden because of the nuclear
statistical weight rules.

And so this is a way
you can surprise people,

because you know something
that's far more sophisticated than you're supposed to know. Or that you can figure
out in a short time.

Because it's easier to know
about rotational selection rules and that sort of stuff.

OK, so I've now lulled you
into a sense of confidence that, bring it on.

I'll classify the
levels and I'll tell you what are the
nuclear statistical weights. And which are going
to be the existing

levels and non-existing levels. And all I have to
do now is write this molecule on the
board and you will say,

uh oh, I don't know-- yes. AUDIENCE: What if
we were to do HD?

ROBERT FIELD: All
the levels exist. All the levels have the same
nuclear statistical weights. There's no permutation
symmetry in HD,

because the protons and the
deuterons are different. So you have a nuclear spin
of 1 for the deuterium, 1/2

for the hydrogen. And so you
can have total nuclear spin of 3/2 an 1/2.

And so the degeneracy for the
3/2 is 4 and for the 1/2 is 2.

So every level will have a
nuclear spin degeneracy of 6.

And there's no intensity
alternation or none. It's trivial.

And that turns out to
be a very useful thing, because for example,
in the attempt

to assign the spectra of
a molecule, a permutation symmetry, you are always going
to have intensity alternation.

But if you have an isotopically
substituted molecule, you won't.
And so there is an easy way.

It's not foolproof, because if
you have a transition starting from an initial
state, say k equals

2, where the asymmetry
splitting is small, well then you will also not
resolve the nuclear spin

species and you will not
see intensity alternation. But if you have fully resolved
rotational transitions,

the presence of
intensity alternation

is a unique sign you
have a homonuclear--
a molecule with symmetry.

OK, so we have 2
bosons, 2 fermions.

What do we do? How do we write
rotational levels that are classified that have
the right permutation symmetry?

You permute 2 hydrogens,
the overall wave function has to be odd.

You permute the 2 carbons,
the overall wave function has to be even. How can you do that?

Because our naive idea is
we rotate the molecules, odd Js are odd, even Js are even
with respect to permutations,
and you're sort of stuck.

Do half the levels not exist
because of oxygen analogy? Or do half the levels
have nuclear spin of 1--

have degeneracy of
1 and the other half of have the degeneracy of 3?

These two possibilities
are not compatible. So how do we resolve this?

And the way we resolve this
is we resort to something else

that we know. What we know is about symmetric
double minima potentials.

Suppose we have a
nice fat potential. And so here is v equals
0, v equals 1, v equals 2,

v equals 3.  And suppose now we either
chop this in half or just

put in a nice big barrier. Let's just put it in a nice
big barrier in the middle.

OK, well, v equals 1
hardly sees the barrier.

And v equals 3 hardly
sees the barrier.

AUDIENCE: Because
of [INAUDIBLE]?? ROBERT FIELD: Yeah.

So half the levels are not very
much affected by the barrier.

And if we chop the
potentials in half, those levels would still
exist, and the other levels would be blown into
the stratosphere.

They would no longer
exist if we said it's only a half potential.

OK, remember something about
that I told you, probably.

And that is, you can tell the
vibrational quantum number from the number of nodes.

And so well, what's
going to happen here?

Well, suppose we draw
the wave function. It's going to hit the barrier.
It's clearly not going to work.

It might tunnel
through the barrier, but it can't possibly go to
0 at the other turning point.

So how do you fix that? Well, if you raise
this level, then it can start to be decreasing.

And if you raise it
more to this energy,

you can get to the point where
it's almost going to 0 when it gets to the barrier.

And so what you do
is keep raising it so that it can tunnel
without crossing 0.

And you end up
having a state that looks like that instead of a
state that looks like this.

And they're at the same energy. Or depending on how
big the barrier is,

there'll be a small splitting. But the beautiful thing is
when you approach it this way,

you see that the node count is
still the thing that tells you the order of the states.

The lowest level
will have no nodes, but it will happen to
be almost perfectly

degenerate with the next
level that has one node. And the same thing happens here.

This next state,
it gets pushed up. And so what you end up having,
instead of equally spaced

levels as you did
without the barrier,

you have levels which arrange
themselves like this, 0, 1, 2,

3. And the spacing of
these two is 2 omega y,
which is equal to 1 omega 0.

So if you took
half the potential, you would have states
that are separated

by twice the frequency. And this was
qualitatively reasonable. When you make a
potential narrower,

the levels get farther apart. When you make the
potential half as wide, you might expect that the levels
will get twice as far apart.

Although that requires
using the WKB quantization condition to prove.

You know about that. OK, so-- AUDIENCE: I have a
question, right here.

ROBERT FIELD: Yes? AUDIENCE: So I
understand the idea

that you can shift
up this wave function and it sort of has to end up
looking like that [INAUDIBLE]..

ROBERT FIELD: Yeah.  AUDIENCE: I guess I don't
understand what it is about--

I mean, so I can imagine
you have a potential and then you start
putting a barrier in.

ROBERT FIELD: Yeah. AUDIENCE: The barrier-- I imagine a barrier that
you continuously bring up.

So what is it about the
barrier coming in that actually pushes the level up?

OK, that was just-- ROBERT FIELD: Well, there's many
ways to answer that question.

One is that the wave functions
have to go to a 0 at infinity. And so once they penetrate
into the forbidden region,

they have to have the
right slope so that they can go to 0 at infinity. If they can't do that, they'll
go to infinity at infinity.

And so there's an
exactly right slope that they have to have here. And so they have to fit.

And so you know how to
calculate a tunneling integral, you know can propagate
the wave function

into the forbidden region. And so you just
have to move it up. And so if you can't use
up much action in here,

then you have to
pretty much go up to the level of the
next higher state.

And this gives you
this wonderful picture that this and this are
exactly degenerate.

And that we normally
think of this as an oscillator on the left,
an oscillator on the right.

And we can take linear
combinations of them. And so we can have a
local mode on the left and a local mode on the right,
but those aren't eigenstates.

The eigenstates have to respect
the symmetry of the problem. And so the real
states are these.

But by taking sums and
differences of these, you can have something on the
left or something on the right.

And that also says, well,
if you have a big barrier, nobody knows that there's
anybody on this side.

So what ends up
happening is that when you have a large barrier
between two symmetrically

equivalent structures, you get
two levels that are degenerate.

They are degenerate, but
they have different symmetry.

And so for acetylene, if we
label the levels H1CaCbH2,

well, there's another
molecule, H1CbCaH2.

There are two identical
structures, two bonded

networks, which are identical. And there are only two, as
far as I can figure out.

And so that means that
every level of acetylene is a symmetric and
anti-symmetric combination

of these two bonded structures. And so they are going to have
different symmetries according

to plus and minus. And this is the
answer to the problem.

That if you write
a wave function as the symmetric or
anti-symmetric combination

of two bonded
networks, you can write wave functions which satisfy the
condition for boson or fermion.

Or boson and fermion as
you have in acetylene. And so what you find is that in
the case of normal acetylene,

every level is doubled, every
rotational level is doubled. But in the case of
acetylene, one doesn't exist.

It has 0 statistical weight.  And the other one has
statistical weight of 3,

because that's what the
hydrogens do for you, or 1.

One of them-- I'm sorry, I said it wrong. One of the pair
always doesn't exist.

The other one of the pair
has a statistical weight of either 3 or 1. So acetylene looks
exactly like hydrogen.

But what's hidden is
there's really two levels. And when you-- wait, you have
to do the group theory right,

and all sorts of additional
insights come out. But superficially,
acetylene treated

as a linear molecule, a rigid,
not vibrating linear molecule,

it rotates like this. And the rotational levels are
classified exactly the same way

that the rotational levels
of hydrogen are classified. And it just happens that one
member of each tunneling pair--

well, you could call
it tunneling pair. Each member of each
degenerate pair, one of them

is always absent. Which one is absent
requires something that I had hoped that
I could do for you.

So anyway, this brings
us to the formal tool

that enables us to deal
with identical particles in the same molecule.

And it's called CNPI, Complete
Nuclear Permutation Inversion

Group Theory. And the beautiful
thing about CNPI

is that it's based on
rigorous symmetries. Group theory that we all
learn, point group theory,

is based on a fiction. It's based on the idea that
molecules are rigid and frozen
at their equilibrium geometry.

It's very powerful,
and we've learned it and we can do magical
tricks with it and all the tricks are right.

But that's an accident. The rigorous symmetries
are permutations

of all identical atoms. All possible permutations of
identical atoms and inversion.

Space inversion,
not body inversion.

And now here, I'm starting to
go beyond my current knowledge. Space inversion is not
inversion through the center

of coordinates. Space inversion is like going
from a right handed to a left

handed laboratory frame. But this is something that
I'm not so sure about. And I'd rather not
say much, except that

in the case of acetylene
where we have--

we're labeling the
hydrogens as 1 and 2 and the carbons as A
and B. So we would want
to consider things like this.

So these are obvious. These are permutations of the-- I can never remember--
the hydrogens.

These are permutations
of the carbons. And these are not feasible,
because that would involve breaking two bonds.

But there are
legitimate questions. If we had a bag of atoms,
that would be something
that we'd care about. This is legitimate. So this is identity.

This is end over end rotation,
or its equivalent to that.

And these are the inversion
times this operation.

There are eight of them.  This group is called G8, the
complete permutation inversion

group for HF dimer,
acetylene, vanillidine.

Anything that has two pairs
of identical atoms is G8.

It doesn't matter what
the rigid structure is. And this is one of
the beauties of it, because this is what enables
you to go between states

of one potential
where you have one qualitative type
of rigid structure and another potential where you
have a different qualitative

type of structure. Because you don't care about the
usual point group operations.

You care about things
that are rigorous and that have
consequences in terms

of the fundamental symmetry
of bosons and fermions and stuff like that.

So-- AUDIENCE: Is it obvious
that one can never have breaking two
bonds at the same time?

ROBERT FIELD: Well,
you can, actually. AUDIENCE: Purposely-- ROBERT FIELD: Well, suppose-- I mean, suppose we start
with this and we go to--

OK. So we've taken one hydrogen
around, made vanillidine.

And then we take
the other hydrogen back to where the first one
came and we've permuted.

So we've used vanillidine
as a transition state in the conversion
of this to that.

So yeah, you can
have it, it just happens at very high energy. It just happens that
we're really interested

in it happening because
when this happens, it tells us that
this is happening. We're really interested in this.

We're not so interested in that. So when the tunneling
through the barrier

between this structure
and that structure starts, it's because of a level of this
that we want to know about.

And CNPI group theory
is going to tell us how to get that information.

In fact, whenever
you start to have tunneling between
qualitative structures,

there will be a group
theoretical signature of that. That I can say with confidence.

What that signature
is, I wish I could say, but I leave that to the
smart people in the room rather than the someone who
can't learn anything anymore.
OK, so we have a group.

And since there are
eight operations, there are eight irreducible
representations,

all one dimensional. And so we need to classify all
of the interesting things--

electronic wave function,
vibrational wave function, rotational wave function,
nuclear spin functions--

according to the irreducible
representations of G8.

Now, there's two ways
of labeling them.

The old fashioned way,
which is reminiscent

of ordinary point
group symmetry. And then a different way, where
we have a symbol here, which

is either S or A,
and a symbol here, which is either lowercase S or
lowercase A, and a symbol here,
plus and minus. 2 times 2 times 2, 8.

So this is more useful
label because it reminds you of what it's
for, whereas here you have

to sort of remember some stuff. And so-- except I don't remember
which is the capital letter

and which is the
lowercase letter and I have written
down somewhere I hope.

Yeah, here it is. So this is the carbons and
this is for the hydrogens

and this is parity.  So we have eight irreducible
representations that

can be labeled in this way. And our job is to put these
irreducible representation

labels onto the
vibrations and rotations of the various
isomers of acetylene.

And the easy thing
is vibrations. The hard thing is rotations.

And I really did expect that
I could do this, and I can't.

But there is one thing
that I can tell you, and that is when we talked about
asymmetric tops or any kind
of--

we had labels JKa
or Kp, Kc, or Ko.

And these labels are
sufficient to map

onto the four irreducible
representations of the molecular rotation group.

And Ka, Kc-- even-even,
even-odd, odd-even, odd-odd--

we factored the rotational
Hamiltonian into four blocks. The four blocks had
labels according

to the odd or evenness of the
Ka and Kc basis functions.

There are no interblock
matrix elements. And there is a 1
to 1 correspondence

between these symbols and
irreducible representation labels in G8.

And that's where I
can't act as your guide,

because I thought I
had it worked out, but every mnemonic I've
used has inconsistencies.

So I would really suggest that
you spend some time with this

paper by Jim [INAUDIBLE],,
which I find--

at the time when he wrote it,
I thought it was wonderful because I thought I understood.

But it's not wonderful
enough, because I can't get an understanding
of the subject to lecture to you from this paper.

This paper is from my
